pages:
STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
December 17, 2021
Kathleen Schultz
Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
1715 Sutherland Dr. SE
Kentwood, MI 49508-5072
RE: License #: CB410201260
Investigation #: 2022C0112002
Dear Ms. Schultz:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 Be signed and dated.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200, 121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
611 W. OTTAWA  P.O. BOX 30664  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov/lara  517-335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE AGENCY
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB410201260
Investigation #: 2022C0112002
Complaint Receipt Date: 11/18/2021
Investigation Initiation Date: 11/19/2021
Report Due Date: 01/17/2022
Licensee Name: Wellspring Lutheran Services
Licensee Address: 4100 Pier N. Blvd Ste. A
Flint, MI 48504-1487
Licensee Telephone #: (989) 262-7386
Administrator: Kathleen Schultz
Licensee Designee: Kelly Bowers, Designee
Name of Facility: Wellspring Lutheran Services Kentwood
Facility Address: 1715 Sutherland Dr. SE
Kentwood, MI 49508-5072
Facility Telephone #: (616) 281-4601
Original Issuance Date: 12/01/1991
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 06/29/2020
Expiration Date: 06/28/2022
Capacity: Unknown
Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
There has been a lack of responsiveness from the agency during Yes
emergencies.
There has also been a lack of needed support services referred. No
Foster parents are not being paid the correct DOC. No
III. METHODOLOGY
11/18/2021 Special Investigation Intake
2022C0112002
11/19/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Notification to Chief Administrator of SI
11/19/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Email sent to complainant notifying her that an SI has been
opened.
11/19/2021 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
Phone interview with complainant
11/24/2021 Contact - Telephone call made
Interviewed complainant by phone
12/01/2021 Inspection Completed On-site
Interviews conducted via Teams due to COVID related safety
concerns
12/02/2021 Contact - Face to Face
Interviewed Program Manager and Supervisor via video
conferencing
12/07/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Multiple email exchanges with agency staff to gather information
12/15/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Email sent to PM for follow-up information request
12/15/2021 Contact - Document Received
Email response from PM
12/16/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Email exchange with PM
12/16/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Pre-exit email sent to Director and Program Manager reporting
preliminary findings
12/16/2021 Inspection Completed-BCAL Sub. Compliance
2

ALLEGATION:
There has been a lack of responsiveness from the agency during emergencies.
INVESTIGATION:
On 11/18/2021 I received a copy a complaint submitted through the DCWL on-line
reporting system by a foster parent alleging that the agency has not been responsive
to calls made to the on-call worker outside of traditional work hours.
Interviews
On 11/24/2021 I interviewed Foster Parent (FP) by phone. She reported Youth A
was placed in her home on 10/12/2021 and was removed on 11/23/2021 at her
request. During the time Youth A was in her home, she made 3 calls to the agency’s
on-call worker that were not answered. She stated that on a 4th occasion, she called
the on-call worker, which was not answered, but called back within the hour. She
indicated all of the calls were related to crisis occurring in the home due to Youth A’s
behavior.
On 12/2/2021 I interviewed the agency Program Manager (PM) and the Director
responsible for supervising the case via video conferencing. PM & Director reported
they were aware FP had called the on-call phone sometime in mid to late October
and did not receive a response. PM & Director stated the worker who had the phone
at the time slept through that phone call. They stated that they were not aware of
any other calls made by FP that were not answered, but they would look through the
on-call phone history.
On 12/7/2021 I received an email from PM identifying the worker (FCW1) who was
responsible for sleeping through the call made to the on-call phone by FP. PM
reported that FCW1’s supervisor has met with her to address this concern. PM
stated that she looked through the on-call phone’s call log to determine if any other
calls from FP were missed or not returned timely but did not locate any.
Document Review
On 12/6/2021 I reviewed a copy of the agency’s on-call procedure provided by
Director. The procedure states that the on-call worker must return all missed calls as
soon as possible, but not more than 30 minutes after the missed call.
On 12/6/2021 I reviewed a copy of the agency’s Placement Agreement Between
Foster Parents and Wellspring Lutheran Services which was signed by an agency
worker and FP on 1/21/2021 which states that the agency will provide FP with an
afterhours on-call telephone number for emergency calls. The document states that
the on-call worker will do their best to return calls within 30 minutes.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all of the following:
3

(e) Staff responsibilities.
ANALYSIS: Foster Care Worker 1 slept through an after-hours crisis phone
call made by Foster Parent and did not return the call within the
required 30 minutes as dictated by agency policy.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
There has also been a lack of needed support services referred.
INVESTIGATION:
On 11/18/2021 I received a copy a complaint submitted through the DCWL on-line
reporting system by a foster parent alleging that the agency did not refer the youth to
needed services in a timely manner.
Interviews
On 11/24/2021 I interviewed FP by phone. She reported when Youth A was placed
in her home on 10/12/2021 she was informed by agency staff Youth A was receiving
Wraparound services and counseling in another county prior to being placed with
FP. She stated that she did receive Serious Emotional Disturbance Waiver (SEDW)
paperwork needed to receive Wraparound services, but those services had not
started at the time the complaint allegation was submitted and the assigned foster
care worker (FCW2) told FP on three different occasions that she had “just”
submitted the referral, causing FP to doubt if or when the paperwork had been
submitted. FP reported that she was also told Youth A qualified for Enhanced Foster
Care (EFC) services, which also had not been started at the time the complaint
allegation was submitted.
On 12/2/2021 I interviewed the agency Program Manager (PM) and the Director
responsible for supervising the case via video conferencing. PM reported Youth A
was receiving Wraparound services prior to placement with FP, but when the youth
was moved to FP’s home, which was in a different county than the previous
placement, the service had to be stopped in the previous county then re-started in
FP’s county. As far as the EFC services, PM stated that it did take some time to get
started as the agency was initially trying to shuffle caseloads amongst workers in
order for an internal worker to provide the services, but they were unable to make
that work so they had to contract out to another agency to provide the service, which
started on 11/22/2021, just prior to Youth A leaving FP’s home.
Document Review
On 12/7/2021 I received and reviewed an email from PM stating:
 On 10/20/2021 FCW2 completed a referral for EFC services.
 Agency staff attempted to adjust caseloads in order to allow room on an agency
caseworker’s caseload to provide EFC services internally, but due to staffing
issues, they were not able to do so.
4

 Additional paperwork and information gathering was completed by Director, PM,
and FCW2
 On 11/15/2021 the agency submitted a request to the West Michigan
Partnership for Children (WMPC) as required in order to request permission to
partner with another agency to provide EFC services.
 On 11/17/2021 WMPC approved the request.
 On 11/18/2021 another agency agreed to accept the EFC case of Youth A.
 On 11/19/2021 the EFC referral was completed and submitted.
 EFC services started on 11/22/2021.
On 12/16/2021 I received and reviewed an email from PM stating:
 Wraparound services for Youth A started 6/9/2021 in his placement county.
 Wraparound services ended in the county in which Youth A was placed when he
moved to a different county on 10/12/21 and was placed in FP’s home.
 The required paperwork an approval process for transferring Wraparound
services from one county to another took approximately 4 weeks.
 Wraparound services began in FP’s home on 11/9/2021.
APPLICABLE RULE
MISEP 6.20 Provision of services
DHHS shall ensure that the services identified in the service
plan are made available in a timely and appropriate manner
to the child and family and shall monitor the provision of
services to determine whether they are of appropriate
quality and are having the intended effect.
ANALYSIS: The services for which Youth A was assessed and approved to
receive are being provided.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Foster parents are not being paid the correct DOC.
INVESTIGATION:
On 11/18/2021 I received a copy a complaint submitted through the DCWL on-line
reporting system by a foster parent alleging that the agency did not secure an
appropriate Determination of Care rate based on the youth’s needs.
Interviews
On 11/24/2021 I interviewed FP by phone. She reported when Youth A was placed
in her home on 10/12/2021 she was informed by agency staff that Youth A was
receiving Wraparound services and counseling in another county prior to being
5

placed with FP and also qualified for Enhanced Foster Care (EFC) services;
however, she did not receive any Determination of Care payments and only received
the daily foster care rate payment.
On 12/2/2021 I interviewed the agency Program Manager (PM) and the Director
responsible for supervising the case via video conferencing. PM reported the most
recent worker has completed current DOC paperwork. PM reported she doesn’t
know why FP wouldn’t receive DOC payments since Youth A qualified for and was
receiving a DOC 3 rate in his previous placement.
Document Review
On 12/2/2021 I reviewed Youth A and FP’s case files in MiSACWIS. I located the
SED Waiver Payment Request and Approval (DHS-1254) form. This document was
signed by FP on 10/27/2021 and approved on 11/1/2021. This form documented that
a SEDW DOC rate was approved on 11/1/2021. FP’s provider record documented
those payments were made to FP at the approved SEDW DOC rate for each day
Youth A was placed in her home.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 903-3 WAIVER FOR CHILDREN WITH SERIOUS EMOTIONAL
DISTURBANCE (SED WAIVER)
Community Mental Health and MDHHS determines eligibility
and approval for the SED Waiver. A foster parent or a relative
who is receiving foster care payments for a child enrolled in
the SED Waiver Project is eligible for the $50 per diem. The
SED Waiver approved rate is only applicable to foster care
payments.
Once the local MDHHS office receives notification from the
Waiver Support Application (WSA) of the child’s eligibility for
the SED Waiver the worker must route the DHS-1254, SED
Waiver Payment Request and Approval, to the behavioral
health analyst in the Child Welfare Medical Unit for approval
and signature. The behavioral health analyst will approve and
route the service authorization to FCD for final approval.
Note: Children receiving the additional rate for the SED Waiver
are not also eligible for a DOC or a treatment foster care rate.
ANALYSIS: The foster parent’s case record documents that she was paid
the appropriate and approved rate.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable CAP, I recommend no change in the license status.
6

December 16, 2021
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
December 16, 2021

7
